title: Territory of Gad and Reuben
shortSummary: Numbers 32 recounts the request of the tribes of Gad and Reuben to settle on the east side of the Jordan River due to their large cattle herds. Moses initially rebukes them for discouraging the Israelites but agrees after they promise to help conquer Canaan. The chapter concludes with the allocation and building of cities in the promised land.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - Wilderness Wanderings after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who mediates the request of Gad and Reuben and ensures their commitment to the conquest of Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: Eleazar the Priest
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who is consulted alongside Moses and tribal leaders regarding the land request.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Gad and Children of Reuben
keyCharacters.description: Two Israelite tribes who request land east of the Jordan for their cattle and agree to fight alongside the other tribes.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ appointed successor and military leader, mentioned as one who wholly followed the LORD.

definitions.definition: Enclosures or pens built to protect and contain sheep, indicating pastoral lifestyle.
The land or property given to each tribe or family as their possession, often by divine allotment.
God’s righteous judgment and wrath against disobedience and unbelief among His people.
The land or territory that a tribe or individual owns and inhabits.

outline.heading: Request for Land East of Jordan
outline.description: The tribes of Gad and Reuben observe the fertile land suitable for their cattle and request to settle there instead of crossing the Jordan. This reflects their practical concerns but also initiates a significant negotiation.

outline.heading: Moses’ Rebuke and Reminder of Past Failure
outline.description: Moses confronts them about discouraging the Israelites, recalling the previous generation’s failure at Kadeshbarnea and warning of God’s anger if they do not fully commit.

outline.heading: The Promise to Assist in Conquest
outline.description: Gad and Reuben assure Moses they will fight alongside the other tribes until the land is subdued, after which they will settle east of the Jordan. Moses accepts their pledge and commands the leaders accordingly.

outline.heading: Land Allotment and City Building
outline.description: Moses grants the land of Sihon and Og to Gad, Reuben, and half of Manasseh. The tribes build fortified cities and sheepfolds, establishing their presence east of the Jordan.

application: Commit fully to God’s calling and responsibilities rather than seeking comfort or convenience.
Support and encourage fellow believers in their spiritual journey rather than discouraging them.
Honor promises made to God and others, especially in service and obedience.
Trust God’s provision and timing when facing decisions about inheritance and possessions.

keyVerses.text: But if ye will not do so, behold, ye have sinned against the LORD: and be sure your sin will find you out.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the seriousness of covenant faithfulness and the certainty of divine accountability.

keyVerses.text: Save Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenezite, and Joshua the son of Nun: for they have wholly followed the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the example of wholehearted faithfulness to God amidst widespread rebellion.

keyVerses.text: We will not return unto our houses, until the children of Israel have inherited every man his inheritance.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates the tribes’ commitment to communal responsibility and unity in God’s plan.
